paper_name: Tackling Over-Smoothing for General Graph Convolutional Networks
method_summary: The DropEdge method is proposed to alleviate the over-smoothing issue in Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs). It operates by randomly removing a certain number of edges during each training epoch. This dropout-style operation is shown to either slow down the convergence of over-smoothing or reduce the information loss resulting from dimensional collapse. The technique serves both to provide a form of data augmentation and to enhance the expressiveness of GCNs by retaining essential node features and fostering diversity in the input data.
experiment_summary: Extensive experiments conducted on several real-world benchmarks demonstrate that DropEdge consistently improves performance across various GCN architectures, including both shallow and deep models. The results illustrate its effectiveness in counteracting over-smoothing, as well as in enhancing overall classification accuracy when applied to GCNs.
